review.title: Non-Monotonic Spatial Reasoning with Answer Set Programming Modulo Theories
review.abstract: The systematic modelling of dynamic spatial systems is a key requirement in a wide range of application areas such as commonsense cognitive robotics, computer-aided architecture design, dynamic geographic information systems. We present ASPMT(QS), a novel approach and fully-implemented prototype for non-monotonic spatial reasoning --- a crucial requirement within dynamic spatial systems --- based on Answer Set Programming Modulo Theories (ASPMT).

sections.heading: 2 SPATIAL REPRESENTATION AND REASONING
sections.text: Knowledge representation and reasoning about space can be formally interpreted within different frameworks such as: (a) geometric reasoning and constructive (solid) geometry (Kapur and Mundy 1988); (b) relational algebraic semantics of "qualitative spatial calculations" (Ligozat 2011); and (c) axiomatically constructed formal systems of mereotopology and mereogeometry (Aiello et al. 2007). Independently of formal semantics, healthy spatio-linguistic abstractions provide a human-centered and cognitively adequate mechanism for logical-automated reasoning about spatio-temporal information (Bhatt et al. 2013).Research in qualitative spatial representation and reasoning has been driven primarily by the use of relative algebraic semantics.

sections.heading: 3 ANSWER SET PROGRAMMING MODULO THEORIES
sections.text: The semantics of stable models is the most widely used theory of non-monotonous thinking with important practical applications. It is able to express a number of non-monotonous and standard types of argumentation, e.g. causal effects of actions, a lack of information and various assumptions of completeness (e.g. the absence of ramifications resulting in state restrictions) (Gelfond 2008), which makes it very attractive for thinking about space, actions and change in an integrated way. In the following, we present a definition of stable models based on syntactical transformations (Bartholomew and Lee 2012), which represents a generalization of earlier definitions from (Ferraris et al. 2011), (Gelfond and Lifschitz 1988) and (Ferraris 2005).

sections.heading: 3.2 Turning ASPMT into SMT
sections.text: An SMT instance is a formula in a much sorted first order formula, i.e., with fixed meaning (by a background theory) of designated functions and predicate constants. Then, the SMT problem is to check whether a given first order formula, i.e., with a model that extends the background theory. ASPMT is a generalization of ASP analogous to a generalization of SAT that works with SMT (the syntax of ASPMT is the same as the syntax of SMT).It is shown in (Bartholomew and Lee 2013) that a narrow portion of ASPMT instances can be converted into SMT instances and, as a result, off-the-shelf SMT solvers (e.g. Z3 (De Moura and Bjørner 2008) can be used for arithmetic superreals to compile stable models of ASP.

sections.heading: 5 ASPMT(QS) – SYSTEM OVERVIEW AND IMPLEMENTATION
sections.text: The implementation of ASPMT (QS) is based on aspmt2smt (Bartholomew and Lee 2014) - a compiler that translates a narrow fragment of ASPMT into SMT instances. Our3 Regional Connectivity Calculation (RCC) is a spatial logic of topological relationships between regions (Randell et al. 1992). Theory is based on a single connectivity predicate C (x, y) interpreted as topological closures of regions x and y that have at least one common point (i.e. the regions touch each other at their boundaries or their interiors).The system consists of an additional module for spatial thinking and Z3 as an SMT solver. Since our system operates on a narrow fragment of ASPMT, input programs must meet certain requirements described in the following paragraph. As an output, our system either produces the stable models of the input programs or determines that there is no such model.

sections.heading: 8 CONCLUSION AND OUTLOOK
sections.text: We have presented ASPMT (QS), a novel approach to arguing about space and spatial changes within a KR paradigm. By integrating dynamic spatial reasoning within a KR framework, namely responses to programming (module theories), our system can be used to model behavioral patterns that characterize high-level processes, events, and activities as identifiable in terms of a general characterization of common sense in terms of space, actions, and change (Bhatt 2012; Bhatt and Loke 2008). ASPMT (QS) is able to develop a solid and complete spatial reasoning, and to combine qualitative and quantitative spatial information if they do not argue monotonically; this is due to the approach of coding spatial relations as polynomial constraints, and the solution with SMT solvers for the theory of real nonlinear arithmetics.

Dynamic spatial systems are characterised by scenarios where spatial configurations of objects undergo a change as the result of interactions within a physical environment (Bhatt and Loke 2008); this requires explicitly identifying and formalising relevant actions and events at both an ontological and (qualitative and geometric) spatial level; for instance:

• within the context of geographical information systems, formalising high-level processes such as desertification and population displacement based on spatial theories about appearance, disappearance, splitting, motion, and growth of regions (Bhatt and Wallgrün 2014); • within a domain such as (commonsense) cognitive vision from visual imagery (e.

, video, point-clouds etc), the ability to perform spatio-linguistically grounded semantic question-answering about perceived and hypothesised events based on a commonsense qualitative model of space and motion (Suchan and Bhatt 2016a).

Independent of formal semantics, commonsense spatio-linguistic abstractions offer a human-centred and cognitively adequate mechanism for logic-based automated reasoning about spatio-temporal information (Bhatt et al. 2013).

metadata.abstractText: The systematic modelling of dynamic spatial systems is a key requirement in a wide range of application areas such as commonsense cognitive robotics, computer-aided architecture design, dynamic geographic information systems. We present ASPMT(QS), a novel approach and fully-implemented prototype for non-monotonic spatial reasoning —a crucial requirement within dynamic spatial systems— based on Answer Set Programming Modulo Theories (ASPMT). ASPMT(QS) consists of a (qualitative) spatial representation module (QS) and a method for turning tight ASPMT instances into Satisfiability Modulo Theories (SMT) instances in order to compute stable models by means of SMT solvers. We formalise and implement concepts of default spatial reasoning and spatial frame axioms. Spatial reasoning is performed by encoding spatial relations as systems of polynomial constraints, and solving via SMT with the theory of real nonlinear arithmetic. We empirically evaluate ASPMT(QS) in comparison with other contemporary spatial reasoning systems both within and outside the context of logic programming. ASPMT(QS) is currently the only existing system that is capable of reasoning about indirect spatial effects (i.e., addressing the ramification problem), and integrating geometric and qualitative spatial information within a non-monotonic spatial reasoning context.
